captions.text:
I thought my life was over. I had no purpose.
I found that I couldn't sleep at night. Then

I realized there's more Half-Life to review;
the PC, or definitive, version of Half-Life

2, to be exact. And yeah, it's still just
as satisfyingly awesome nearly ten years after

its release. And in that time, many have explained
why it's so great, so there's not much I can

really add. But just in case you haven't played
Half-Life 2, let me explain yet again why

it should be played by everyone.
Believe it or not, I try to avoid fanboy gushing

in a review. That being said, it's very hard
to find any significant faults with Half-Life

2. Sure, the loading interruptions can be
a little jarring and long, but considering

the fact that the game is essentially continuous,
they can be easily excused. And this may surprise,

but it does take second place to the original
Half-Life for me. I may be alone there, but

I can definitely acknowledge Half-Life 2's
technical superiority, which applies to both

gameplay execution and, obviously, graphics.
First of all, Half-Life 2 looks great. The

facial details are impressively expressed
in characters, and this can be seen almost

immediately upon starting the game. Of course,
graphics are a huge step up from the original

game, which was released six years prior,
but the world is more significant in premise

rather than because of technical execution.
Half-Life was confined to the Black Mesa research

facility; although certain areas looked unique,
the general theme was that of, well, a research

facility. Half-Life 2's story takes Gordon
Freeman out of the research facility, and

instead you take control of the mute protagonist
years after the initial Black Mesa incident.

The alien race, known as the Combine, have
taken over the planet, and thus created a

typical military-controlled, police state
dystopian future. But instead of now being

confined to a dystopian metropolis, the game
also takes Freeman to coastlines, canals,

and zombie-infested towns. Half-Life 2's journey
and sense of progression certainly contribute

to the game's ethereal appeal and represent
a change from the original Half-Life's escape

theme.
Of course, there's a much more tangible appeal

to Half-Life 2. Well, as tangible as digital
murder can be. The game retains its hard-to-describe

shooting feel. But I can say that shooting
is responsive and satisfying regardless of

the weapon and inability to aim down the sights.
The targets are changed up as well; instead

of the more outlandish aliens of its predecessor,
Half-Life 2 adds a second helping of humanoid

foes that more closely resemble the marines
of the first game. It's not necessarily a

good or bad thing, but the improved physics
that come along with it certainly make a kill

feel more significant. The relatively mild
puzzle and platforming emphasis is here, and

does a lot to set the game apart from a pure
first-person shooter standpoint, along

with a few unique weapons. Certain sections
of Half-Life 2 also take a more explorative

approach. The game is still very linear (again,
not a bad thing), but a few chapters allow

access to a vehicle of some kind, a large
open area, and some optional areas to look

into. It's nothing that greatly contributes
to a major aspect of the game, except for

an achievement, but it's done well and appreciated.
Half-Life 2 does nearly everything right.

Each chapter provides a new experience or
gimmick, but unique and enriching gimmicks.

So not gimmicks; let's say "gameplay evolutions".
And those "gameplay evolutions" also make

Half-Life 2 so impressive. It doesn't just
feel like an improved sequel, but its own

separate stage in the evolution of Half-Life.
Hopefully, we'll see the next one soon, but

that's irrelevant. As with the best games,
it's hard to put exactly into words what makes

Half-Life 2 great. Sound familiar? Well, it
should, and it's true, in my humble opinion.

But regardless of opinion, Half-Life 2 should
be played by everyone, if not to just see

what people were, are, and will be talking
about.
